titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Asian Garment Workers in New York City Oral History Collection OH.018
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Unattributed Tamiment staff and David A. Olson

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-12-11T17:20-0500

change.item: Finding aid created by David A. Olson incorporating description by unattributed Tamiment staff

did.unittitle: Asian Garment Workers in New York City Oral History Collection

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 1 card catalog drawer and one shared manuscript box.

did.abstract: The collection consists of interviews of garment workers who came to New York City from Vietnam, China, the Philippines, and California. Interviews are primarily with International Ladies Garment Workers' Union members and staff (especially Local 23-25), but one interview is with a garment manufacturer. Topics covered include emigration to the United States, working conditions, joining the ILGWU, and major strikes. The majority of the interviews were taken in 1989 by Bichiluyen Nguyen of NYU's History Department. Interviews were taken in English, Chinese or Vietnamese, and indexes or transcripts exist in English for all interviews.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, Vietnamese, and Chinese.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Depending on the interview, copyright is held by the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives or is unknown.

Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Content is open for research without restrictions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Bichiluyen Nguyen donated the tapes in 1989, except for the Chishti interview, which was deposited by the Asian/Pacific/American Institute in 2004.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Access compact disks are arranged alphabetically. Master cassettes, indexes, and transcripts are arranged according to an archivist-devised numbering system.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Collection rehoused and labeled sometime after 1989. Entire collection digitized in 2013, and a full finding aid was written at this time.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Asian Garment Workers in New York City Oral History Collection; OH 018; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of the original audio media, researchers must use access compact disks.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: NYU undergraduate Bichiluyen Nguyen, herself a Vietnamese immigrant, conducted most of the interviews as part of an internship in the History Department in 1989. The exception is the interview with Muzaffar Chishti, which was taken in 2004 by Winifred Chin, a research affiliate at the Asian/Pacific/American Institute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of six interviews with garment workers who came to New York City from Vietnam, China, the Philippines, and California. Interviews are primarily with International Ladies Garment Workers' Union members and staff (especially Local 23-25), but one interview is with a garment manufacturer. Topics covered include emigration to the United States, working conditions, joining the ILGWU, and major strikes.

did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Vietnamese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Interview includes discussion of Bui's youth in Vietnam, immigration to the United States, the clothing business that Bui owned in the Bronx, and his views on challenges contracting with clients and negotiating with unions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The interview discusses Chishti's work with undocumented workers during his years as director of the Immigration Project at the ILGWU. Topics include the union's activities to aid such workers, social and legal concerns, and lobbying activities.

did.langmaterial: Interview questions are in English and answers in Chinese. Index in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Interview includes discussion of Ka's youth and education in China and Hong Kong and her work in the People's Republic of China there as a doctor. Also covered are different working conditions in textile industry in Chicago and New York, strikes in early 1980s, disputes with Italians, and worker wages.

did.langmaterial: Interview conducted in Vietnamese. Index is in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Interview includes discussion of youth in Philippines and Hong Kong, immigration to United States, activities as a business agent for union, and strike in Chinatown shops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Interview includes discussion of strikes in the 1980s, union's education department, Coalition of Labor Union Women, new immigrants, and real estate in New York City and Chinatown.

did.langmaterial: Interview conducted in Vietnamese. Index in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Topics discussed include youth in Vietnam, conditions in factories and for textiles workers who work at home, wages, and employment with Paul Bui's Princess Mai Company.
